docs.lead_paragraph: Headache. Backache. ''Job burnout.'' Emotional problems. Whatever ails an employee, his employer is likely to feel worse when the bills have to be paid. Americans spent more than $245 billion on health care in 1980, according to the Government's Health Care Financing Administration, and the United States Chamber of Commerce says employers paid nearly half that. By 1983 the national health bill could equal 10 percent of the gross national product, according to a study commissioned by the Health Insurance Association of America and prepared by the former chief medical director of the United States space program, Dr. Charles A. Berry.

docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE IN a departure from the traditional curriculum, a number of Long Island universities have entered the field of preventive sports medicine, offering sports fitness programs to the public on the premise that emphasis on cardiovascular conditioning may not only reduce the risk of heart attack but also lead to physiological rejuvenation. Some professions - albeit privately - question the validity of university involvement in health-related commercial ventures, which may provide a good source of revenue for the institution. Others believe that the benefits of such programs are considerable, seeing them as offering a great potential for educators to play an affirmative role in helping to develop life styles geared to maximum health. Dr. Paul Samuel, a cardiologist affiliated with the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center in New Hyde Park and president of the Nassau County chapter of the American Heart Association, offered a positive evaluation about what he called ''good benefits'' accruing to many continuing programs developed to help keep the public fit.
